job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Boise, ID

pros: Adequate break room but have to answer the phone during breaks!

review_title: Love my job and the people I work with
job_title: Payer Auth Specialist in Boise, ID
pros: Saint Alphonsus is the best healthcare system in Idaho hands down. For many reasons, and taking into consideration many friends and acquaintances experiences, I just wouldn’t go anywhere else for healthcare in Idaho.
cons: No downsides except the nature of healthcare itself is a real negative these days.

job_title: Executive director of nursing in Boise, ID
pros: The culture in this organization impresses me on a daily basis. We have leaders at all levels leaning in with frontline colleagues to continually work to improve their daily work and promote patient safety. I am really happy to be working in this organization!!
cons: Healthcare is tough right now and like every organization, we have a lot of travelers.

pros: Fair pay, growth opportunities, great benefits.
cons: Could do a better job with salary transparency and communicating caps

pros: Good leadership team that helped direct the group forward.
cons: Opportunity for advancement seemed minimal.

pros: I have loved working for Saint Alphonsus in many roles now for over 20years. I love the culture and opportunity to care for people well.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Baker City, OR

review_title: Job is great but onboarding is a very long process.
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Boise, ID
pros: They are very flexible with your schedule, especially if you are a student. There are also always a shift to pick up if you need extra hours. The people who work there are also really kind and always willing to help you if you need it.
cons: The onboarding process took almost a whole month. Communication was also touch and go. There is a shortage of nurses everywhere, so you will work with more patients then you normally would, but like I said that goes for all hospitals.

job_title: Area Practice Manager in Boise, ID
pros: Only have wonderful things to say about the individuals you work with at Saint Alphonsus. Great people trying to do the right thing. Some of the most talented Doctors I have ever worked with.
cons: Really difficult to get things done quickly as you have to follow all of Trinity Healths policies and procedures. Takes an extremely long time to get things to move do to approval processes etc. I am all about stewardship, but when it comes at the cost of losing valuable staff it becomes difficult.

pros: Decent hours and sign on bonus
cons: Micromanagement with supervisors, fairly high turnover.

cons: Not an APP-friendly environment Don't feel like I'm working to the maximum of my ability Lack of professional growth path for APPs; if you want to move up, you have to move on wRVU incentive, but lack of opportunity to make them Administration tries, but are out of touch

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Boise, ID

review_title: the most transparent HR & Management I've ever experienced

pros: None, this place is a misery pit! All of the workers are miserable and look like they hate life! All they do is complain! The vibe is horrible! Just don’t!!! pros: Many great people with decent benefits and average pay.
cons: Like many places there is some toxic management and infighting that can make for an extremely dissatisfying workplace. Being watched down to the minute with clocking and out feels demoralizing.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Fruitland, ID

cons: Policies are not enforced unless management wants it to. Get a copy of every paper you sign. Make sure all your days off and or arrangements with a supervisor or manager is in writing, ie text, paper, email....

review_title: Great place to work - great benefits

cons: Healthcare is tough no matter how you look at it right now. I wish more would come back to the workforce because this work is so rewarding.

job_title: Patient Data Registrar in Boise, ID

pros: Trauma experience is a plus.
cons: Bad management from the higher ups

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Boise, ID
pros: if you are lucky you can get a boss that cares about your work and home life balance. You can get a really good team that works on communication.
cons: benefits are all right but not the best. Getting recognition is hard as well as moving up.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Boise, ID
pros: The bullying I experienced from my preceptor was so bad I didn't get a chance to stay long enough to even figure out what was good about this hospital. I wish I had a better experience, to be able to share with you.
cons: I would not recommend taking a new grad residency at this hospital. They are hurting badly from the effects of covid, and training is chaotic to say the least. I experienced nurse bullying, to the point I had to leave and not come back. Save yourself time because you will not love this. HR will treat you as if you are the problem as well, they will act like you are making it up.

review_title: Great work/life balance and supportive leadership
pros: I came to Saint Alphonsus after becoming burnt out elsewhere, and was looking for a workplace where I didn't constantly feel like I was being run ragged. I have been here for 3 years now and feel so supported, listened to, and encouraged by my leaders and colleagues. I'm proud of the mission and values of the organization, and feel like I'm actually contributing to it rather than just preaching about it. Saint Alphonsus cares about their patients, colleagues, and community!
cons: Like most healthcare organizations in the country, there are some staffing gaps, high turnover, and some positions' pay isn't as competitive as it should be. Overall, compared to other healthcare organizations in the community, I had a much more positive experience at Saint Alphonsus.

pros: Flexible schedules if you work in the right clinic.
cons: Nepotism runs rampant throughout this company. It is difficult to get in the door and once you do, to have any hope of getting anywhere, you better learn the right butts to kiss.

pros: Able to practice autonomously as a NP
cons: PTO and holidays are combined.

pros: Helpful colleagues good resources fun place to work
cons: No privacy in case of emergency event, no protocol

pros: The building is nice and warm
cons: The staff is not friendly, the manager is rude and says strange things ( on my first day he said “we can be friends but if you do anything wrong we won’t be friends”) also someone else was hired for my shift. Pay is horrible. You’re not allowed to butterfly needles on patients that would need one because they are “expensive”. They care more about money than they do their patients. Also my first week employees were looking for other employment and complaining about st. Al’s.

pros: The money was good at the time
cons: Little or no positive feed back - taken for granted

review_title: Fake non-profit greedy corporation that doesn’t live up to is mission, vision, and values
pros: It was close to my house
cons: Low pay, little to no raises, extremely poor management. Good luck getting any issues resolved from HR or payroll, they are all located in another state and dont care about your problems. Nobody has any real answers, even your managers can’t help you or know the answer or are empowered to fix a problem. Upper management complains about short staffing yet they won’t make more part time positions available or pay people a decent wage to keep employees. But of course executives all make fat salaries with cushy perks and bonuses. Its a mega corporation, so its not much different than working at Walmart as a door greeter.

pros: Fair pay, many nice coworkers
cons: Disorganized, poor management, zero support from managers, abusive pharmacy manager

pros: Good coworkers, good place to start a career.
cons: Healthcare can be a challenging industry.

pros: Great company to work for! The hiring process went extremely smooth despite having so many things to accomplish before my first day of work. There was a lot of communication along the way. My training process was smooth and the Medical Assistant who trained me was very competent and he answered all of my questions with ease and provided me with guidance. I feel extremely fortunate to work for such a great company. I work for a great team of medical professionals and feel encouraged
cons: Pay is extremely low for people who have experience and the pay scale needs to be re-evaluated to be more competitive especially for the amount of responsibility.

pros: Great co-workers, good benefits, enjoyable work.
cons: Pay is low, always short-staffed, lots of pressure to work extra, treated as less-than in organizational hierarchy, lack of respect and recognition.

pros: I am new to St. Al's and I have yet to meet someone who wasn't cheerful and easy to work with.

pros: Imposible yo get fired, even if you don’t do your job.
cons: The pay does not correspond with the duties, risks, and expectations of CNAs. They not only do patient care but also transport, house keeping, monitor tech, unit secretary duties, etc. The expectations are high which is great but the company doesn’t match the same expectations for themselves when it comes to taking care of their employees. Offering sign up bonuses and not retention bonuses. Sad

pros: 1- Health Insurance 2- 403-B

review_title: It's alright for a non-degree requiring job

pros: I work in the Emergency Room. Easy job with lots of variation. I work 3 - 12's so the long weekends are nice. Decent benefits but could use improvement. No micromanagement!!
cons: Nearly constantly short staffed, must be independent to be able to succeed in your job. VERY religious and at times I've felt forced to participate in religious practices that I did not want to partake in. Wish there was more choice and more inclusiveness. I can be non-religious and still be a good person and hold similar values as other religious people.

- Hospital orientation was excessive
- I have already heard some employees complain they do not feel appreciated by the healthcare system as a whole

job_title: Medical Representative PSR in Boise, ID
pros: There is a good mission. Benefits are alright, IF you stay long enough for them to not to be pulled (company matching retirement and tuition assistance for higher education).
cons:
Over worked. In two years, there I don't think I ever got more than a 30 minute break when I had time to take a break (60 minute breaks were supposed to be the requirement). Most employees are doing 2-4 times the position they were hired for all the way up to managers. My manager was the manager of three clinics when I left. 
The pay is meager. It is an extremely stressful environment with little reward.

pros: Good people to work with

review_title: There's a need for a culture revival-priority changes
pros:
1. As far as the position I worked in, it seemed like the learning curve was pretty easy to grasp.

2. I was able to be physically walking around the hospital to visit with patients, but also had time to sit and enter data. There was a healthy balance.

3. I enjoyed my team for the most part, and have great memories from interacting with patients.
cons:
1. Tons of people are leaving (in general) not simply because of COVID, but because the Leadership is failing to invest in their staff for the quality/quantity of work they provide.

2. In my specific department, there were six (6) manager/director position changes within three years. I don't care where you work, that ain't good.

3. There is a massive ruling from Trinity Health that overrides anything your locational hospital might want to achieve.

pros: great place to work, yes

review_title: Steady raises and good benefits! But when it comes down to it you are expendable!
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Boise, ID
pros:
Fairly good benefits package
Yearly bonuses and raises at least one per year
cons:
Requiring the new COVID vaccines for employees before they are FDA approved!
Upper management shares little concern for employee input.
You are expendable, no matter how critical you are to fulfilling the hospital's mission!

pros: Small hospital with close knit working relationships
cons:
Staff and staffing is constantly mishandled.  There is a lot of turn over of staff.  The old guard so to speak in terms of experience were pushed out or left.  This leads to the blind leading the blind.   This is a small hospital and people use it as a stepping stone to initiate their careers.  This may be (admittedly) why most stay about a year or two max.  

Differential pay is constantly being changed to benefit the company.  If you work extra when Saint Alphonsus needs help during a week they will offer differentials/incentive pay but take it away later in the week if they put you on call.   This happens very frequently.  They pay into your 401k at the end of the year now.  If you don’t stay the whole year, you are out of luck.

They just fired the managers with 10-20 years experience to place much less qualified people into their positions.

pros: Great doctors and people to work with
cons: Bad management. Overusing employees for very low pay

cons: Trinity health is a large company,onboarding process is long,monotonous and not very personable.

cons: night shift work, hours available.

pros: The culture of the organization of taking care of others is very strong.
cons: The various electronic systems make it hard for cohesive communication.

pros: Great team of people to work with
cons: none that I can think of

review_title: Professional, Great Morale, Leadership Shows Appreciation
pros: Caring Loving Professional Team Oriented
cons: none none none none none

job_title: Pre Service Specialist in Boise, ID
pros: Great benefits and job security.
cons: Over worked and under paid.

pros: Catholic values, good intentions, patient safety big priority
cons: sometimes decisions come from larger health system (Trinity)

pros: There is a lot to learn, gain experience
cons: There is a poor nurse-patient ratio

review_title: Former Employee who went on to greener pastures....
pros: It was good to have a job with so many people out of work in this country. Provided in-depth orientation and training at start of employment, but it was so poorly organized that it took twice as long as was needed.
cons: Benefits cut dramatically in last 3 years. Poor staffing patterns. Yet management continues to be "fat cats" with big salaries, big bonuses. Management parking lot empty every weekend and every afternoon after 3 o-clock. Highly political environment that requires that you partner with clicks to be successful. Lack of support from management. The computer system - a creation of the Trinity system who owns the hospital - is a mistake waiting to happen. Not user friendly. Makes nurse prone to mistakes. Medical records are riddled with mistakes.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Boise, ID
pros: Good pay and great benefits.
cons: Too many to list, know what you are getting into.

pros: Honestly I only stay because pay us better than any other job in the area would pay for a customer service type job. Benefits are pretty good.
cons: Too much work for staff to handle. Managers would rather have you quit and replace you with another desperate person than to spend the money to hire extra help. No consistency with training and each clinic has different guidelines. Managers are micro managers and have NO idea how to work a front office. They target who they want to get rid of and do whatever sneaky behavior they can to fire them. HR is useless. There is no one to turn to if you have a complaint or concern.

pros: I can't speak of other departments, but depending on how busy the hospital may be,  somedays may be very busy, while other days are so slow, we just can just relax. It's so nice to have days where you can just sit around and chill, although they still want us to try remain busy.
cons: Although my boss has been great to address any complaints, unfortunately a lot of things are out of his control. For instance, our department are among those that still gets paid the least despite doing much more than our job description. Upper management doesn't know what we all do, and if they did, we would probably told not to do it, but if we didn't do it, CNAs and nurses would complain we don't help them enough getting patients ready to be transported.

pros: Saint Alphonsus Health System has great benefits, and appreciates all of  the employees.  The campus is beautiful, and all the staff are very friendly.
cons: Saint Alphonsus Health System has a live your whole life program to encourage wellness.  While it has good intentions, it is a bit misguided.  It seems odd to offer points and get credit for attending courses on financial well-being, yet going to the on-site gym (or any gym) is not counted and no credit is given.  More courses/options for obtaining credit should be available, including gym membership, and proof of attending the gym (on-site gym requires badge in access), and most local gyms have a key card they scan to allow you to use them. It would be simple for staff to print a monthly report of the number of times they went to the gym.

review_title: The Salaries and benefits need to be higher, and staffing ratios need to improve
pros: You can obtain part-time work with flexible hours
cons: Poor retirement benefits.  Offers no medical or dental insurance in retirement. Retirement package isminimal, and so is matching of 401K.  Benefit package needs to provide better medical benefits to families, and have better coverage.  Staffing ratios need to improve.  There needs to be more Supportive  services for patient care, such as more CNA's, and orderlies.

job_title: Imaging Patient Care Specialist II in Boise, ID
pros: Co-workers and managers really care about patients. When I first started they had a bigger program to help with college and workplace advancement. Insurance used to cover anything you did within the system
cons: The computer programs do not integrate well with each other. There is a clear difference between clinic and hospital software that do not communicate with each other. They are working on getting a new system that will fix this issue but the lack in urgency worries me. It can take months for the hospital to adapt to any change. Communication can be the worst.

pros: The evening supervisor at the time was amazing. I wouldn't necessarily call this job flexible, but since I was part-time, the supervisor would often work with my college schedule. However, I did not see the same cooperation with the full time staff. The job was nice while in school since it gave me experience in a hospital without being mentally strenuous.
cons: The job was very hard on my body. I had to get a back brace withing the first couple days of working. People outside of the EVS department can be belittling and ask EVS staff to do cleaning jobs that are not EVS responcibilty.

pros: Easy parking and clean facilities.
cons: Management plays favorites. It is a popularity contest for who gets promoted. New ideas to improve work flow, productivity, patient safety, are dismissed immediately. You are treated like a number. The best way to get by was to not be noticed. Management publicly embarrassed employees. Talking behind coworkers backs was commonplace even by management. Providers and mid levels would constantly talk down to nurses with no repercussions. There was no sense of teamwork. An environment of negativity was constant. management Covers this all up by constantly talking about their religious connections and being a health ministry. They don’t care about patient safety, they don’t care about nurses. They only care about their profits. To top it all off the pay was no where near enough to make up for cost of living expenses.

review_title: I was appalled when I found my documentation altered!
pros:
The pay was generous. Co-workers were awesome. 
Office Manager was supportive of clinical staff.
Central location was nice. Nice benefit package.
cons:
I was happily employed there until 3 months later, they tried to change my job description, and hours & days worked from what was agreed upon in the interview. 

I also happened upon some documentation I had turned in previously, and discovered someone came along behind me & altered a physicians phone order I had written. I was beyond irate. 

They received some negative press in the local paper in regards to their recent survey and it was all true in my experience there.

pros: Co-workers who care about their patients and each other is what I like most about my job at SARMC.  My nurse manager has strong leadership skills.
cons: Compensation is not adequate at SARMC and continues to be an issue with nurses on the unit where I work.  The physicians on my unit do not appear supportive or interested in the nurses opinions.

review_title: Great organization that truly lives its values.
job_title: Human Resources Director in Boise, ID
pros: Leaders are committed to the organization's mission and generally try to live the values.  Pay and benefits are very good.  Strong emphasis on wellness and work life balance.  Great internal development programs for individuals that want to gain RN or MA education at no cost.
cons: As with most large organizations communication can be challenging at times.  Large companies can be slow to react to changes in market.  Staffing is lean.

pros: Close to home. Nice co workers and Doctors. New building, (but poorly designed facility!) Health insurance. Can not think of any other good things!
cons: Very poor communication from management. Raises that do NOT even come close to keeping up with the cost of living in the Treasure Valley! The way Scheduling is set up is a huge area of dissatisfaction! No input as to which Holidays or weekends you want to work, just told which ones you will work! Many current staff looking for new jobs because of scheduling issues!

pros: You get to know your regular patients, rarely are people upset with you.
cons: I rarely get off work on time, no breaks, and feel guilty when I take time off or need to leave early for illness. The pay certainly doesn’t reflect the work or the market Idaho is in, I could get a job at a gas station for a dollar an hour less with a quarter of the stress and responsibilities.

pros: Good collaboration between healthcare providers within specialty group and other professionals within the hospital system
cons: Support lacking for specialties groups that are overworked and burnt out (e.g. PRN help or Locums when # of personnel below need).  Lack of appreciation/acknowledgement of hard work and extra hours.  Insufficient pay for specialty and extra hours/call nights taken above high volume pay

review_title: They are a very caring place to work for. They look after there employees with respect to thier needs
pros: It is one of the better places I've worked with P.T.O.  and the health benefits are great for a family.
cons: the only thing I can think of is that the training is not alaways there when you need it. there are times when you would be put in a postion and had to just figure it out on your own

review_title: The organization is not very good to their non-management employees.
pros: It's nice to have health insurance coverage even though it's too expensive. You can meet some nice people and development relationships.
cons: Low pay. Expected to do the work of at least 2 people. No overtime allowed. No support. No benefits or incentives for non-management employees other than expensive health insurance.

review_title: Good place to work, just don't make enemies.
pros: Great to work for an organization that helps people and the community.  Good ability to have a life outside of work and take care of family and personal things when they come up.
cons: Very political.  Make the wrong enemy and you could be limited in your career.  Compensation leaves a little to be desired.  Increases (if you get one) are very small.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Boise, ID
pros: Great benefits, great pay and countless opportunities for career growth! They will help with the cost of continuing education and want to see their employees well taken care of!
cons: Employee parking could improve but otherwise I have no other complaints!

pros: You receive great support from the Asst. VP's in able to complet your assignments and tasks.  It's a great organization that challenges you regularly to improve and not accept the status quo.
cons:
Hard to get together for meetings because of the managers' work load and the short time frames to achieve objectives
.

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Meridian, ID
pros: Working with the patient 's one on one. Since being in a corporation you have the time to teach/explain there chronic condition.
cons: Toward the end it was more about seeing patients and moving them out the door to meet there financial needs

pros: Food is expensive but pretty decent. Worked with some very decent and caring people.
cons: Overworked, understaffed, unappreciated and morbidly underpaid.

review_title: I worked for Saint Alphonsus for a little over 4 years.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Baker City, OR
pros: Great benefits, great culture, supportive upper management. Good chances for advancement. Great training and benefits.
cons: Little support from lower management, low pay for high workloads. Little work/life balance. Low staffed.

review_title: Saint Alphonsus is a great company to work for and I am excited to see the changes coming.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Boise, ID
pros: Great benefits, health, dental, vision.
cons: Management at some locations only care about meeting the bottom line.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Ontario, OR
pros: Worked in a 49 bed hospital with access to larger facilities an hour away. Enjoyed patient diversity and autonomy in my position on night shifts.
cons: Small hospital purchased by larger franchise.  Some dehumanizing of the staff.  Decreased staff and many policy changes.  We were spoiled by seasoned co-workers but new grads much cheaper to employ.

review_title: Ok place to work, great co-workers
job_title: RN Case Manager in Boise, ID
pros: nice facility, caring co-workers, ok place to work, they tout their religious beliefs a lot, which would be a pro for a Catholic, but con for others.
cons: Overbearing system office (trinity Health), leadership that can't make a decision on their own, creating poor work environment.

pros: Decent benefits pakage, nice new building to work in. Co-Workers are awesome and always willing to lend a hand, especially in tough situations.
cons: Pay is extremely dissapointing, been employed for many years and make what a new hire makes in my same position.  No opertunity for advancement, senior and middle managment see you as just a number and not as a real person.

pros: Family-like atmosphere, faith-based care, administration engaged, and both employees and patients are valued.  Stability is great.
cons: In some non-clinical areas, there can be a lack of advancement opportunities.  Work-life balance is sometimes questionable.

pros: Great benefits and reasonable pay.  Primary employer for medical field.
cons: The hospital preaches it's Catholic values but does little in practice.  As a result it is a pretty passive aggressive, phony culture.  The people who put on the best front usually get promoted which perpetuates the cycle.

pros: Good PTO system. Not much else.
cons: Laboratory is constantly short staffed. Phlebotomy supervisors are always individuals with ZERO phlebotomy experience. Lab is routinely blamed for mistakes made by providers and nursing staff. Pay is worse than any other hospital in the valley and as a result you are constantly working with and training inexperienced new phlebs just to see them quit in six months. Repeated call-outs and understaffing ensure frustration and hostility between hospital departments and the lab. Just a never-ending miserable gripe fest.

pros: Ease of transitioning between clinics, benefits, retirement, generous PTO
cons: Low pay, excessive work load without additional staff to meet demands of providers.

pros: Great folks work here. Decent nurse-patient ratios (when we're fully staffed).
cons: Don't consistently get raises. They took away several benefits 3 years ago, including matching our 403b contribution.

pros: Awesome culture focused on mission and values. Friendly colleagues that are always willing to help. Lots of opportunity to grow and advance. Meaningful work!!
cons: I honestly can't think of any.

pros: Values driven, patient centered and mission oriented. Fun, caring employees who truly care for each other and the work they do.
cons: There are pockets of poor management.  These leaders don't embrace change and are allowed to stay negative instead of working on being positive or offering solutions.

pros: Good employee atmosphere if you’re male. Middle and upper management had an idea of how to make it work.
cons: Corporate did not give them the control they needed to handle their own

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Ontario, OR
pros: I love the people that I work with, and I enjoy the opportunities that they have provided me to advance my career
cons: The health insurance is expensive, for less than great coverage. Administration is more concerned with their bottom line than patient care or staff

job_title: Medical Assistant in Baker City, OR
pros: It hard to come up with a pro for this company. I can't think of 1 pro I can say.I really can't think of a positive thing.
cons: Where should I start? No organization,low pay,no loyalty,no appreciation,no joy in the fact that you are replaceable even though a person's dedication has been in place.The harder you work and try,the more you get shut out.

pros: healthcare, getting time off is fairly easy
cons: policies are often not followed. pay is all over the place for the same job

review_title: The Power of Positive Employment Culture
job_title: HRIS Analyst Lead in Boise, ID
pros: Saint Alphonsus fosters a work environment of equality and acceptance.
cons: It is a Catholic faith-based organization, but they do not discriminate (or tolerate discrimination) based on religious beliefs.

pros: Strong, moral, Catholic values.  Good work-life balance.  CEO is really a good guy.
cons: Growing company, more merging, which is part of the business.  However, this means some decisions come from the non-local level, which can be frustrating.

pros: Great people in the organization.
cons: Stressful environment with a chronic understaffing issue throughout the organization.

review_title: I'm leaving for the same reason
pros: I enjoyed the people I worked with but many clinics are drastically different.
cons: Doctors are unhappy with insurance requirements and many are leaving Saint Alphonsus who refuses to stand up to said insurance companies.

pros: SARMC was a great hospital to work for before they were taken over by Trinity Health.

pros: Great Co workers. Managers vary unit by unit. But it's that way in every hospital
cons: Joined Trinity Health a few years ago. Benefits have gone down hill since

job_title: Supply Chain Technician in Boise, ID
pros: Healthcare isn't going anywhere and job was solid.  Loved my supervisor.  Benefits at the time were good.

pros: Co-workers were all great to work with

pros: Great co-workers and the manager at this clinic rocks!

pros: It is  a great work environment with a lot of good people to work with.

pros: Great environment, good pay and employee recognition
